awd_titl_txt: CRISP 2.0 Type 2: Collaborative Research: Organizing Decentralized Resilience in Critical Interdependent-infrastructure Systems and Processes (ORDER-CRISP)
awd_abstract_narration:
This Critical Resilient Interdependent Infrastructure Systems and Processes (CRISP) project develops an integrated resilience modeling framework for mitigating vulnerabilities in critical interdependent infrastructure systems. The framework evaluates the coupled nature of vulnerabilities across physical and social systems in Miami and Houston. By focusing on the effects of recent hurricanes on the interdependent-infrastructures in energy, water, transportation and telecommunication, and the human-infrastructures interactions, the project explores options for resilience. The system vulnerabilities are quantified with regional inoperability based economic-interdependency models. The project will develop an app for information sharing with the public.  Thus, this scientific research contribution supports NSF's mission to promote the progress of science and to advance our national welfare with benefits that will optimize investments in the nation's critical infrastructures.  

The project integrates risk-based models, agent-based simulations, dynamic models of social vulnerability, and models of economic impacts of inoperability. The novelty lies in integrating the interdisciplinary research components: (i) incorporating wind and flood inundation risk into the utility and service disruption models to analyze and determine the extent of interdependent infrastructure failures in energy, water, transportation, and telecommunication sectors; (ii) constructing socio-infrastructural systems of vulnerability and analyzing evacuation/relocation behavior to assess the need for emergent critical infrastructure services; (iii) micro simulation for analyzing coping behavior and facilitating decentralized resilience through information sharing and critical resource pooling; (iv) a macro (city level) inoperability based resilience model to integrate household and social responses with disrupted interdependent infrastructure systems; and (v) developing an app to facilitate and scale up participatory resilience through crowd-sourcing which will be usable in other disaster settings. The project will engage, mentor, and offer an innovative active learning environment for K-12, undergraduate, and graduate students by giving priority to the disadvantaged and underrepresented communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Hurricanes bring strong winds and heavy flooding, often causing major disruptions like power outages, water and sewer system failures, communication breakdowns, and transportation issues. To help communities recover faster, it’s important to build resilient infrastructure that can quickly return to normal after a storm. This project aimed to understand how hurricanes impact essential infrastructure services and develop strategies to make critical infrastructure more resilient. One key focus was studying how people and infrastructure interact during emergencies, including evacuation and recovery patterns. To do this, we created a computer-based simulation to model these systems and explored whether alternative data sources like social media could help track infrastructure failures and recovery patterns.

The project made multiple important advances. First, the project explored various data sources to understand the nature and extent of infrastructure disruptions. For instance, quickly identifying infrastructure failures during a disaster is crucial for fast restoration of services. Traditional physical sensors have limitations, such as the challenge of covering large areas quickly. To address this limitation, we developed a method to analyze social media posts to detect multiple types of infrastructure disruptions. Additionally, we developed a mapping tool that effectively shows the precise location of a disruption. Using Twitter data from hurricanes Irma and Michael, we showed that our approach outperformed other methods to detect infrastructure disruptions. By identifying different types of disruptions and their locations, this research will help utility companies and disaster management teams coordinate more efficiently, improving response and restoration efforts.

Second, the project developed methods to understand how communities are affected by a hurricane and how quickly they recover. Using aggregate location data from Facebook during Hurricane Ida in Louisiana, we measured community resilience—how much the disaster impacted daily life and how long it took to return to normal. We found that communities lost resilience due to three main factors: damage to infrastructure (e.g., power and transportation services), the severity of the hurricane itself, and socioeconomic conditions. Communities with lower median incomes experienced greater difficulty in recovering. Similarly, understanding how electric power is restored after a storm can help communities recover faster. However, studying power outages requires detailed data from utility companies, which is often private and not widely available. We developed a new approach by using location data from Facebook to analyze power outages during hurricanes. We found that Facebook data can explain 59% of the variation in daily power outages and 65% of the variation in restoration times. These studies demonstrate the value of social media data for studying infrastructure disruptions and community recovery patterns.

Third, evacuation is one of the critical ways to stay safe during a hurricane. While many studies have looked at the factors that influence whether people choose to evacuate—such as risk forecasts, socio-demographics, and environmental cues—it’s less understood how these factors work together to shape a household’s overall risk perception and decision to leave. We developed a computer simulation that models how households decide whether to evacuate before a hurricane. We considered various factors, including flood risk, household characteristics, social networks, and neighbors' choices, to simulate evacuation decision-making. We also investigated how different sources of information—and how much people trust them—affect evacuation behavior. We found that people are more likely to evacuate when they trust hazard warnings. Social networks encourage more people to leave but also increase unnecessary evacuations, as people may follow their neighbors instead of official advice. These insights can help emergency managers develop better strategies for risk communication and evacuation management.

Fourth, since different infrastructure systems rely on each other, restoring services can take even longer when multiple systems are disrupted. We developed a computer simulation that models how power and transportation networks recover after a hurricane. The model includes key elements such as the electric grid, roads, storm hazards like wind and flooding, and households. Implementing this model to a community in Miami-Dade County, the study focused on two ways power and transportation systems affect each other: roads are essential for fuel deliveries to power plants and for crews to access damaged power infrastructure; and power outages can disrupt traffic signals and other transportation services. Assessing different restoration strategies suggest that prioritizing traffic signal repairs does not slow down power restoration for households. Also, restoring power is faster when fuel deliveries and repair crews can reach affected areas without road blockages.

In summary, the project produced data, models, tools, and insights that benefit communities by improving disaster preparedness, restoration and recovery efforts. By analyzing social media data, it provides new ways to track infrastructure failures and community recovery in real time. The findings will help emergency managers, utility companies, and policymakers make better decisions, ensuring faster restoration of essential infrastructure services like power and transportation. Ultimately, this research will strengthen community resilience by enhancing disaster management strategies and reducing restoration times after hurricanes.
